questions.text: Match the radiological images given below:
questions.solution:
Football sign is seen in pneumoperitoneum. Due to accumulation of gas within the central abdomen and falciform ligament.

Rat tail sign is seen in Ca esophagus due to narrowing of the esophagus.

String sign is seen in Pyloric stenosis due to narrowing of the pyloric canal.

Inverted umbrella sign seen in TB. It is seen due to ICJ involvement.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2080, 1090, 2182, 168

questions.text: Identify the focal lesion on NCCT Abdomen
questions.solution:
Hydatid disease is caused by the Echinococcus granulosus. On CT scans hydatid cysts have a density of near water attenuation. Daughter cysts when present give the lesions a multilocular appearance or a honeycomb appearance with the multiple septa representing the walls of daughter cyst. The fluid in the daughter cysts has a lower attenuation than that of the fluid in the mother cyst. On contrast administration, the cyst wall does not show enhancement. Only the internal septae enhance. Detachment of the laminated membrane from the pericyst can be visualized as linear areas of increased attenuation or the membranes may be free floating within the cyst. Calcification in the cyst wall is also easily detected by CT scan

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology 1895

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith
Large bowel obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus

questions.text: An elderly female presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has this curvature deformity of spine since childhood and this has been progressive since then. Based on the Abdominal Radiograph given below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pathophysiology: Caecal volvulus occurs when the caecum twists around its mesentery, leading to obstruction and possible ischemia.
  • Risk Factors: Congenital or acquired colonic mobility, previous surgeries, chronic constipation, and spinal deformities (like scoliosis) that alter intra-abdominal pressure dynamics.
  • Radiographic Features:
    • Dilated caecum displaced to the midline or left upper quadrant.
    • Coffee bean sign (classic sign of volvulus).
    • Absence of gas in the distal colon (suggesting obstruction).
    • Sometimes, a "bird's beak" sign on contrast studies.

Other Options:

B. Large Bowel Obstruction due to Fecolith

  • Fecolith (hardened stool causing obstruction) usually leads to sigmoid or rectal obstruction, which appears differently on imaging.
  • Radiographic Clues: It would show a distended colon with a clear transition point near the fecolith, which may be visible as a dense, calcified mass.
  • The patient's history of progressive spinal curvature and the typical radiographic findings favor volvulus rather than an obstructing fecolith.

C. Large Bowel Obstruction due to Sigmoid Volvulus

  • Sigmoid volvulus is more common than caecal volvulus, but:
    • It typically presents in elderly, bedridden patients with chronic constipation.
    • Radiographic Features: "Inverted U" or "omega" sign, with the sigmoid colon forming a large, dilated loop pointing towards the diaphragm.
    • Unlike caecal volvulus, which is often in the right or central abdomen, sigmoid volvulus is more midline or left-sided.

D. Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)

  • SBO usually results from adhesions, hernias, or strictures rather than volvulus.
  • Radiographic Clues:
    • Multiple air-fluid levels and dilated loops of small bowel (>3 cm).
    • String of pearls sign on upright films.
    • The absence of a large dilated cecum makes SBO less likely.

Reference Image: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/cecal-volvulus-2

questions.text:
In a case of Fungal pneumonia, which of the following findings are seen?
1. Interlobular septatations
2. Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidations
3. Pleural effusion
4. Cavitary lesion with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.solution:
Choice A: 2, 3, 4 (Peripheral wedge-shaped consolidations, Pleural effusion, Cavitary lesion with surrounding ground glass opacities)

Radiological Features of Fungal Pneumonia:

  1. Peripheral Wedge-Shaped Consolidations:
    • Seen in angioinvasive fungal infections (e.g., Aspergillosis, Mucormycosis).
    • Represent infarction due to vascular invasion and thrombosis.
  2. Pleural Effusion:
    • Can occur due to inflammatory response or secondary bacterial infection.
    • Common in chronic and disseminated fungal infections (e.g., Histoplasmosis, Cryptococcus).
  3. Cavitary Lesion with Surrounding Ground Glass Opacities ("Halo Sign"):
    • Characteristics of invasive aspergillosis.
    • Ground glass opacity represents hemorrhage surrounding the necrotic fungal lesion.

Why Choice B (1,2,3) and Choice D (All may be seen) Are Incorrect:

  1. Interlobular Septal Thickening (Choice 1) → Not a Primary Feature of Fungal Pneumonia
    • More commonly seen in interstitial diseases like pulmonary edema, lymphangitic carcinomatosis, and some viral infections.
    • Fungal infections usually cause nodular, cavitary, or consolidative patterns, not prominent interlobular septal thickening.

Key Takeaway: Fungal pneumonia typically presents with peripheral wedge-shaped consolidations, pleural effusion, and cavitary lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities (Halo Sign), but not interlobular septations.

questions.text: Boot shaped heart with a history of cyanosis is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Tetrology of fallot consists of pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding of aorta and right ventricle hypertrophy. It is most common cyanotic congenital heart disease in children. The chest xray shows a characteristic appearance of booth shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy causing upturning of the apex of heart.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2588

questions.text: Female of reproductive age group is advised for CECT head, what will you ask her?
questions.solution:
For a female patient undergoing any procedure involving radiation should ask menstrual history as if there is pregnancy in the patient then radiation exposure will lead to fetal anomalies or death.

Reference: Christensen's physics of diagnostic radiology, page no 378

questions.text:
An HIV patient presents with Headache and Altered sensorium. Consider the following evidences about his condition. Which of these is an Absolute Criteria for diagnosis of NCC?
1. Brain biopsy shows Taenia solium
2. MRI brain shows the typical cyst-with-a-dot sign
3. CT showing ventriculomegaly with multiple periventricular calcifications
4. Muscle showing multiple focal calcifications
questions.solution:
Neurocysticercosis (NCC) is caused by the Taenia solium larvae infecting the central nervous system (CNS). The absolute criteria for diagnosing NCC include:

  • Brain biopsy showing Taenia solium → Absolute criterion
    • Direct visualization of the parasite in tissue confirms the diagnosis.
  • MRI brain shows the typical cyst-with-a-dot sign → Absolute criterion
    • This classic imaging feature represents the scolex within the cyst and is highly specific for NCC.
  • CT showing ventriculomegaly with multiple periventricular calcifications
    • This is a supportive finding but not an absolute criterion. Other conditions (e.g., tuberculosis, CMV, or other infections) can also cause similar findings.
  • Muscle showing multiple focal calcifications
    • This suggests systemic cysticercosis but does not confirm neurocysticercosis specifically.

Absolute Criteria for NCC Diagnosis (Del Brutto’s Criteria):

According to Del Brutto's diagnostic criteria, the absolute criteria are:

  • Histological confirmation of the parasite (biopsy).
  • Imaging showing a cystic lesion with a scolex (cyst-with-dot sign).
  • Direct visualization of the parasite in the eye (ophthalmoscopy).

questions.text: Egg-shell calcification is seen in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Choice (b): Sarcoidosis

  • Egg-shell calcification refers to the thin, peripheral rim-like calcification of lymph nodes, most commonly seen in occupational lung diseases.
  • Sarcoidosis typically causes diffuse, coarse, or nodular intrathoracic lymph node calcifications, but not classic egg-shell calcifications.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

  • Choice (a): Silicosis
    • Classic cause of egg-shell calcification of hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes.
    • Strongly associated with occupational silica exposure.
  • Choice (c): Metastatic lymph nodes
    • Certain malignancies (like testicular cancer, ovarian cancer, and thyroid cancer) may cause peripheral calcification of lymph nodes.
  • Choice (d): Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes
    • Radiation exposure can lead to dystrophic calcification, including an egg-shell pattern in lymph nodes.

Key Takeaway:

Egg-shell calcification is NOT seen in sarcoidosis but is a characteristic feature of silicosis, metastatic lymph nodes, and post-radiation therapy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a complaint of painless hematuria. CECT done revealed a mass lesion in the right kidney. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Choice (b): Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC)

  • Painless hematuria is a classic symptom of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC).
  • CECT findings of a mass lesion in the kidney strongly suggest RCC.
  • RCC typically appears as:
    • Heterogeneous enhancing mass on contrast-enhanced CT (CECT).
    • Can have areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, or calcifications.
    • May show tumor thrombus extension into the renal vein or IVC in advanced cases.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice (a): Angiomyolipoma
    • Usually seen in young women and associated with tuberous sclerosis.
    • CECT shows a fat-containing lesion (negative HU values due to fat).
    • Can cause spontaneous hemorrhage, but not typically associated with painless hematuria.
  • Choice (c): Simple cyst
    • Appears as a well-defined, thin-walled, fluid-filled lesion on CECT.
    • Shows no enhancement on contrast imaging.
    • Unlikely to present with hematuria unless very large and compressing adjacent structures.
  • Choice (d): Oncocytoma
    • A benign renal tumor, often asymptomatic.
    • Can appear as a well-circumscribed, enhancing mass on CECT.
    • Often has a central stellate scar, but differentiation from RCC requires biopsy.

Key Takeaway

A renal mass with painless hematuria on CECT is most likely RCC until proven otherwise.

Reference Image: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Gross-appearance-of-renal-medullary-carcinoma-grayish-white-firm-tumor-involving-the_fig6_230678138

questions.text: RTA case, whole body CT scan will not include which of the below mentioned?
questions.solution:
CT polytrauma/multitrauma, also called trauma CT, whole body CT (WBCT) or panscan, is an increasingly used investigation in patients with multiple injuries sustained after significant trauma.

A typical protocol will consist of:

  • non-contrast head
  • non-contrast cervical spine
  • contrast-enhanced chest (arterial phase)
    • scan extent to mid abdomen
  • contrast enhanced abdomen (portal venous phase)

Reference: Jones J, Murphy A, Kusel K, et al. Whole-body CT (protocol). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-9051

questions.text: A 34-week primigravida is detected to have intrauterine fetal demise on USG. The finding of hyperechoic air specks within the blood vessels is known as?
questions.solution:
Choice (c): Robert sign

  • Robert sign refers to the presence of hyperechoic air specks (gas bubbles) within the blood vessels and heart of the fetus, seen on ultrasound.
  • It is an early radiological sign of intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) and occurs due to gas formation from putrefaction.
  • Typically seen 12+ hours post-fetal death.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice (a): Hydrops appearance
    • Hydrops fetalis is characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in fetal compartments (ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, skin edema).
    • It is not a sign of IUFD but rather occurs in conditions like Rh incompatibility, congenital infections, or cardiac anomalies.
  • Choice (b): Spalding sign
    • Refers to overlapping of fetal skull bones due to the collapse of the brain following fetal death.
    • It is a late sign of IUFD, typically seen days to weeks after demise.
  • Choice (d): Maceration
    • Refers to softening and breakdown of fetal tissues due to prolonged retention of the dead fetus in the uterus.
    • It is a clinical finding, not an ultrasound sign.

Key Takeaway: Robert sign (air specks in fetal vessels) is an early radiological sign of IUFD, while Spalding sign and maceration occur later.

choices.text: Increased uptake because of osteoblastic lesion

questions.text: A Patient with history of prostate carcinoma. High Gleason score bone scan done show increased uptake with bone and reduced in kidney and soft tissue. This is reported as super scan. The reason behind it is?
questions.solution:
When interpreting skeletal scintigraphy, the term "superscan" refers to a characteristic pattern consisting of symmetrically intense and diffuse radiotracer uptake in the skeleton with absent or diminished visualization of the genitourinary system and soft tissues. This appearance can lead to false-negative scans for metastasis because the diffuse and symmetric skeletal uptake may obscure individual metastatic foci. It as been hypothesized that increased uptake of radiopharmaceutical by involved bone led to reduced phosphate excretion and diminution of renal activity. The differential diagnosis pertaining to a superscan pattern on skeletal scintigraphy includes diffuse osteoblastic metastasis, renal osteodystrophy, osteomalacia, and severe primary hyperparathyroidism.

Reference: Manov JJ, Roth PJ, Kuker R. Clinical Pearls: Etiologies of Superscan Appearance on Fluorine-18-Fludeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography. Indian J Nucl Med. 2017 Oct-Dec;32(4):259-265. doi: 10.4103/ijnm.IJNM_56_17. PMID: 29142340; PMCID: PMC5672744.
